I have traveled twice now to Hoi An and always wondered about the quality of the made to measure tailors. With that being said I decided to give it a try. I had suits made in Hong Kong, China and Canada before but never in Hoi An. After doing much research I set a day aside to see some of the tailors in Hoi An. I visited roughly 6 reputable shops such as A dong Silk, Kimmy Tailor, Bebe, Vanada and Etc. Keep in mind that all these shops are located pretty much on the same block down the street from each other. I stumbled into Lamy and my impression was more than my expectations. I was greeted my Lien in english and she was very well spoken. I am from Calgary, Canada and this really made myself comfortable in exchanging ideas and what I was looking for. After deciding on what we wanted and finalizing our material we agreed on a price. The price was more than fair and beat all the other bespoke tailors around. With that being said we decided to get measured up. The turn around time was suppose to be a couple of days however Lamy was able to complete it over night. We got measured around 11:30 am and had our second fitting at 18:00 hrs. I was little concerned as all my other second fittings are usually out of place. I came back after some site seeing and WOW it fit as close to as our measurements were. It was almost damm near done. I could have had it completed however there was a world Asia cup and everyone was so excited for the game no work as going to get completed. My suit was not easy as I have a very unique body built but Lamy was able to cater to it and made the suit to what I wanted. The next day we came back to have the final fitting and it fit like a glove. I was totally happy and will be for sure to order more. This is the place to be. reviews: The air was thick with mug and blistering rays of the Vietnamese sun when we left my 4-bed humble hostel room to stroll past the seemingly millions of tailor shops in the quaint but bustling town of Hoi An. I - d heard from a lovely Dutch girl over frozen coconut coffees and banh mi - s laced with avocado that a small white box of a store just steps down the street, past the barbecue pork skewer stall and the mini mart which exclusively sells Oreos and Pringle - s was quite good. But being the modern, eclectic fashion guru that I have grown to be over years of intense study of 17 Magazine and Cosmo, I needed to judge the store for myself. My companion and I headed past said recommended shoppe and into the busier streets where the queen of all banhs rules with an iron baguette and tailors are not mere men but gods. Mannequins, as far as the eye can see, lined the street like an infinite game of London bridge, each adorned with dresses and suits of the highest order. Behind each group was a woman, the puppet master of these polymer models, who drew young, unsuspecting  gringos in with firm kindness.We didn - t stand a chance. With a quick glance at a woman - s outfit and a second too long standing outside, we found ourselves sitting at the back table picking designs and fabric. Unaware that we had already been hooked like an innocent striped bass by a pro fisherman, we succumbed quickly to the charm and knowledge of the petit girl in white and green stripes. But if there - s one thing a fashionista can spot from a mile away, it - s another fashionista, and I looked at her like a sailor finding the North Star after days of being lost in stormy seas. Questions streamed out of us like a rainbow from a pot of gold. I had no idea just how many shades of blue existed. What will go with my eyes? What kind of shape will it take? Will I ever find true love? Like Alex Trebec, this short, unassuming tailor had the answers to all the questions in the universe. When our meeting was concluded, our minds were set, our pockets empty, and our hearts full of hope: hope that soon we would be dressed like the George Clooneys and Jackie Onassis - s of the world. When we returned the next morning, our garments had been built, the i - s dotted, and the t - s crossed. The ordeal was a masterclass of speed and precision. Inhumane factory labor and western supremacy be damned. This suit was sexy. In the moments after leaving those hallowed halls of hemming, I locked eyes with my trailblazing, blazer-buying buddy and felt at peace. Vietnam was a war-torn land. But a truly mysterious and magical metropolis has emerged. And someone - s gonna need a suit. Read more
